div.ab: We will read from yet another image of the Nile.

80. In the thirty-sixth Book Pliny explains
how the Egyptians discovered
a kind of Marble in Ethiopa,
the color of Iron and also hard to pierce,
for this reason called Basalt
In earlier times, Vespasian placed
a figure of Nilus in this Marble
in the temple of peace in Rome.

81. In addition, on this statue too one saw
sixteen Children happily engaging in their joy,
symbolizing the rising of this River;
yet one of the aforementioned Crocodiles
was also in the midst of the youths in this image
to strengthen the virtues of depiction
in which the painterâ€™s whole spirit is free.
Now we should discuss the Roman Tiber.

82. The Tiber image is in the aforementioned courtyard
inside the City of the Academy of Painters,
and artfully depicted with the She-wolf,
who lay there and full of benevolent love,
appeared as Nurse to suckle
the two children Romulus and Remus.
but on his head [the River] has a wreath of leaves,
his right hand is laden with the horn of plenty,

84. Eutychides too in earlier times so artfully
represented in a sculpture the Eurotas,
which is the River of the Lacedemonians,
that it was said by all who saw it
that the work was flooded with art,
much clearer than that water flowing
in the aforementioned River, which, being very foul,
is dedicated to the Furies of Hell.

85. All Rivers and streaming floods
run and turn in curves,
and to imagine in such a way,
were painted with horns, which would
embolden our spirit in depiction.
